questions.title: Patch Antenna Polarization
questions.question_text: A rectangular patch antenna is designed to radiate primarily in the broadside direction. If the patch is oriented such that its length is along the x-axis and its width along the y-axis on a PCB, what is the typical polarization of the radiated field?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct. The polarization of a rectangular patch antenna is typically linear and aligned with the direction of the current flow. In this case, with the patch width along the y-axis, the primary current flow and thus the polarization will be along the y-axis.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Incorrect. The polarization is determined by the current distribution on the patch. Consider which direction the current predominantly flows along the width of the patch.

questions.title: Resonant Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: A rectangular patch antenna has a length ($L$) of 30 mm and a width ($W$) of 40 mm. The effective dielectric constant ($\epsilon_{eff}$) of the substrate is 4.5. Calculate the approximate resonant frequency ($f_r$) of the TM$_{10}$ mode in GHz, using the formula $$f_r =  rac{c}{2L\sqrt{\epsilon_{eff}}}$$, where $c = 3 	imes 10^8\,	ext{m/s}$ is the speed of light.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The resonant frequency is calculated as follows: $$f_r =  rac{3 	imes 10^8}{2 	imes 0.03 	imes \sqrt{4.5}} \approx 2.236 	imes 10^9\,	ext{Hz} = 2.236\,	ext{GHz}$$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check your calculation. Ensure that the length ($L$) is in meters and that you have correctly taken the square root of the effective dielectric constant ($\epsilon_{eff}$). The formula is $$f_r =  rac{c}{2L\sqrt{\epsilon_{eff}}}$$.

questions.title: Substrate Thickness and Bandwidth
questions.question_text: Increasing the substrate thickness of a patch antenna generally increases its bandwidth, but also increases surface wave excitation, which can degrade antenna performance.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct. A thicker substrate typically provides a wider bandwidth due to increased antenna impedance, but it also encourages the excitation of surface waves, which can lead to unwanted radiation and reduced antenna efficiency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Incorrect. While thicker substrates do increase bandwidth, they also have drawbacks like increased surface wave excitation.

questions.title: Effect of Patch Width on Input Impedance
questions.question_text: How does increasing the width ($W$) of a rectangular patch antenna generally affect its input impedance?
choices: Has no significant effect on the input impedance.
Causes the input impedance to become purely reactive.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct. Increasing the width of the patch antenna generally decreases its input impedance. The input impedance is inversely proportional to the width.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Incorrect. Consider the relationship between the width and the current distribution on the patch. A wider patch allows for a larger current flow, leading to a lower impedance.

questions.title: Return Loss Calculation
questions.question_text: A patch antenna has an input impedance ($Z_{in}$) of $75 + j10\,\Omega$ and is connected to a $50\,\Omega$ transmission line. Calculate the return loss (RL) in dB, using the formula $$RL = -20 \log_{10} |\Gamma|$$, where $$\Gamma =  rac{Z_{in} - Z_0}{Z_{in} + Z_0}$$ and $Z_0 = 50\,\Omega$. Provide the answer to two decimal places.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The reflection coefficient is: $$\Gamma =  rac{75 + j10 - 50}{75 + j10 + 50} =  rac{25 + j10}{125 + j10}$$. $$|\Gamma| =  rac{\sqrt{25^2 + 10^2}}{\sqrt{125^2 + 10^2}} =  rac{\sqrt{725}}{\sqrt{15725}} \approx 0.215$$. The return loss is $$RL = -20 \log_{10} (0.215) \approx 6.78\,	ext{dB}$$. Since it is a LOSS, we represent it as -6.78 dB.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check your calculations of the reflection coefficient ($\Gamma$) and the magnitude ($|\Gamma|$). Remember to use the formula $$RL = -20 \log_{10} |\Gamma|$$.
